Line 281: Line 281:
===18 March===
===18 March===
{{wikinews|45 killed after Yemen protesters fired upon}}
{{wikinews|45 killed after Yemen protesters fired upon}}
  +
{{External media
  +
| video1 = {{YouTube|8kZ4x3-oogY|Raw Video: Yemeni Forces Open Fire on Protesters}}
  +
}}
At least 45 anti-government protesters died and over 200 were injured as unidentified gunmen opened fire in Sana'a.<ref>{{cite news|last=|first=BBC News|title=Yemen unrest: 'Dozens killed' as gunmen target rally.|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/mobile/world-middle-east-12783585?SThisFB|accessdate=18 March 2011|newspaper=BBC News|date=March 18, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=|first=BBC News|title=Doctors in Yemen have told the BBC that unidentified gunmen fired on an anti-government rally in the capital, Sanaa.|urlhttp://www.bbc.co.uk/news/mobile/world-middle-east-12789220|accessdate=18 March 2011|newspaper=BBC News|date=March 18, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/mar/18/yemen-police-massacre-45-protesters | title=45 protesters killed in Yemen | accessdate=19 March 2011 | date=18 March 2011 | publisher=The Guardian | archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xIpRum44 | archivedate=19 March 2011}}</ref> Tens of thousands of people also took to the streets in other cities across the country. President Ali Abdullah Saleh has declared a state of emergency across the country, while state media blamed the violence on "clashes among citizens".<ref>{{cite news |title=Yemen forces 'open fire on protesters' |author=[[BBC]] |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12783585 |newspaper= |date=18 March 2011 |accessdate=18 March 2011}}</ref> It has been reported that the attackers were pro-government gunmen, though President Saleh states that his security forces did not fire, and were even unarmed at the time. There are also reports that some of the protesters who were injured in the attack were taken away in national security vehicles to a local prison for treatment instead of to a regular hospital, sparking fears that the injured will be harassed further. The U.S. President Barack Obama and Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, the government of France, led by President Nikolas Sarkozy, and the Common Forum, the coalition of the opposition parties in Yemen, led by [[Ali Mohammed al-Sabry]], all condemned the attack.<ref>{{cite news|last=Almasmari|first=Hakim|title=Yemen imposes state of emergency after deadly attack on protesters|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/protesters-killed-in-yemens-capital-by/2011/03/18/ABFd2hp_story.html|accessdate=19 March 2011|newspaper=[[Washington Post]]|date=March 18, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=France strongly condemns Yemen attack on protesters|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/18/yemen-france-idUSPISIEE78520110318|accessdate=19 March 2011|agency=[[Reuters]]|date=18 March 2011}}</ref>
At least 45 anti-government protesters died and over 200 were injured as unidentified gunmen opened fire in Sana'a.<ref>{{cite news|last=|first=BBC News|title=Yemen unrest: 'Dozens killed' as gunmen target rally.|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/mobile/world-middle-east-12783585?SThisFB|accessdate=18 March 2011|newspaper=BBC News|date=March 18, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=|first=BBC News|title=Doctors in Yemen have told the BBC that unidentified gunmen fired on an anti-government rally in the capital, Sanaa.|urlhttp://www.bbc.co.uk/news/mobile/world-middle-east-12789220|accessdate=18 March 2011|newspaper=BBC News|date=March 18, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/mar/18/yemen-police-massacre-45-protesters | title=45 protesters killed in Yemen | accessdate=19 March 2011 | date=18 March 2011 | publisher=The Guardian | archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xIpRum44 | archivedate=19 March 2011}}</ref> Tens of thousands of people also took to the streets in other cities across the country. President Ali Abdullah Saleh has declared a state of emergency across the country, while state media blamed the violence on "clashes among citizens".<ref>{{cite news |title=Yemen forces 'open fire on protesters' |author=[[BBC]] |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12783585 |newspaper= |date=18 March 2011 |accessdate=18 March 2011}}</ref> It has been reported that the attackers were pro-government gunmen, though President Saleh states that his security forces did not fire, and were even unarmed at the time. There are also reports that some of the protesters who were injured in the attack were taken away in national security vehicles to a local prison for treatment instead of to a regular hospital, sparking fears that the injured will be harassed further. The U.S. President Barack Obama and Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, the government of France, led by President Nikolas Sarkozy, and the Common Forum, the coalition of the opposition parties in Yemen, led by [[Ali Mohammed al-Sabry]], all condemned the attack.<ref>{{cite news|last=Almasmari|first=Hakim|title=Yemen imposes state of emergency after deadly attack on protesters|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/protesters-killed-in-yemens-capital-by/2011/03/18/ABFd2hp_story.html|accessdate=19 March 2011|newspaper=[[Washington Post]]|date=March 18, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=France strongly condemns Yemen attack on protesters|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/18/yemen-france-idUSPISIEE78520110318|accessdate=19 March 2011|agency=[[Reuters]]|date=18 March 2011}}</ref>
